Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: RAPID: How decision-making about risk and interdependencies impact well-being: A baseline study of communities affected by Hurricane Harvey.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this award will develop comparative cases of disaster recovery outcomes to assess best strategies for fostering adaptive resilience in at-risk communities. All proposed sites are located in southeastern Texas and were affected by Hurricane Harvey. They include low-lying coastal and rural agricultural and ranching areas, towns around Beaumont exposed to petrochemicals and flooding, and core urban areas of Houston that were flooded and exposed to contaminated waste waters and industrial refuse. These sites were chosen to represent a range of socioeconomic statuses, ethnic compositions, livelihoods, and exposure risk. The project is innovative in adapting formal decision-making techniques from agricultural contexts to identify factors situated within stories of recovery experiences and overall wellbeing, especially related to risk and the many interdependent factors that produce decisions in the real world. The research will identify variations and similarities in the clusters of salient factors impinging on decisions in order to locate critical points in the recovery process that can support or create barriers to recovery and long term wellbeing. These will begin with the initial big decisions, such as whether or not to evacuate and will progress over the year as new choices arise. Findings from this research will contribute insights into the science of disaster recovery management in the United States, which can lead to more robust, humane, and sustainable recoveries.

The researchers will employ a combination of anthropological qualitative and quantitative methods. Through interviews and participant observation, they will track pivotal moments and everyday life in survivor households, visiting ten households in each of six communities four times over twelve months. In addition to the ethnographic data collection, the investigators will carry out two quantitative household livelihood and well-being surveys at the beginning and the end of the study, and track changes in household and occupational finances. They will also collect biosocial data, including water quality testing to detect the presence or arrival of industrial pollutants, oil or gas residues, and unusual microbial activity. The sum of these household-level data will position this research to develop a series of decision-making models for different categories of choices made by individual survivors and scaled up to model decision-making made by communities, livelihood groups, and other categories of analysis such as class and ethnicity, over the course of the first year of recovery. The project will also provide field-based research experience for two graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Collaborative Rapid Grant: Project Outcomes

This NSF collaborative award enabled the PIs to conduct two years of research following Hurricane Harvey. The big-frame goal of this research entailed an effort to move beyond the narrative of “social vulnerability” that has dominated disaster studies literature for at least 25 years. By researching a wider spectrum of people impacted by disaster in a wider variety of social, economic, and environmental circumstances, we posited that we could collect pilot data in a way that promised new analytical insights and generate potential contributions to new theoretical frameworks.

 

The relevance of Hurricane Harvey for our research goals

People commonly associate Hurricane Harvey with the epic downpour of up to 60” of rain on greater Houston. This historic “rain bomb” created massive damage in the metropolitan areas in and around the city. But Harvey’s impact spanned a diameter of 280 miles and 22 counties Texas, including rural towns with family farms and ranches, semi-rural areas with oil and gas industries, and coastal towns dependent on tourism. Harvey presented the ideal situation for research with impacted people in all variety of life circumstances.

 

Methods and data collection

We made seven field visits to collect data across six impacted counties including Harris County where Houston is located. The counties we targeted presented variations in geography and exposure to risk, population densities, types of livelihoods, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status. Our in-depth interviews represent a small sample of people but varied in ways that correspond to the scope of impacts from Harvey. Our sample includes family farmers and ranchers, coastal townspeople working in tourism or service fields, residents of peri-urban and suburban communities employed in the nearby oil, gas, or chemical industries, urban dwellers living in modest communities and those in prosperous neighborhoods living on higher, professional salaries.

The interviews occurred at three points in time with 30 household heads, for a total of more than 100 interviews. As part of these interviews, we applied our novel decision-making methodology to solicit relevant factors contributing to a series of post-disaster decisions.

We devised a novel methodology for capturing the complexity of factors that may impinge on a given decision. Each respondent identified the influences shaping key decisions from a selection of more than 50 tiles that span social, economic, psychological, environmental, and bureaucratic-related issues. For each decision, the respondents build their own “assemblage” of relevant tiles (using blank tiles to create any new factors not included in the set). The process draws out respondents’ own stories, providing holistic data that we will distill and compare across the sample. Such a context-rich, comparative approach to studying decision-making is rare.

Our preliminary results point to the richness of our methodology for helping probe a new frontier in the study of post-disaster experiences and decisions.

 

Outcomes

Our final fieldwork visit occurred in September 2019, prompted by Tropical Storm Imelda which caused newly rebuilt homes owned by people in our sample to flood all over again. Because of this additional fieldwork, the start of our analysis was delayed, and the outcomes of this project are not yet known. However, we have moved well past data collection: we have transcribed 100+ interviews from our sample and additional interviews with county extension agents, scholars, and scientists working in the area. We have also developed protocols for coding data and expect to complete all coding by end of summer 2020. We will devote the fall term of 2020 to analysis, the development of a book prospectus, and drafts of several chapters. By the end of summer 2021, we expect to have a draft of a book-length manuscript.

In terms of outcomes to date, we have presented five papers and one poster about this work at national and international conferences and mentored five students. This fieldwork also inspired the 2019 Ethnographic Field School for Risk and Disaster, the first immersion program of its kind located on the Texas coast on the island campus of Texas A&M-Corpus Christi.

 

Background, intellectual merit and broader impacts potential

The intellectual merit and broader impacts of this study arise from our critique of the dominant way that social scientists approach the study of disaster. In particular, several methodological patterns of research have limited our view of the social landscape after disaster. These patterns relate to the short time-depth of study, the little-studied rural context of disaster, and the neglect of research with people who have more resources than those people typically considered “vulnerable.” By generating portraits of people who encounter disaster at a particular moment in their life circumstances, our research more fully captures the variations in and dynamic quality of social vulnerability that are inherent in a disaster’s impact. Once data analysis is complete, we expect to publish our outcomes in the book identified above, and in a series of journal articles.
